p.abstract: This sample demonstrates how to use .NET to build a customized, desktop UI for a v4 print driver. This .NET app uses PrintTicket, PrintCapabilities and Bidi in order to communicate with the print system and is suitable for inclusion in a v4 print driver.

desc.note: This sample is for the v4 print driver model.

sectioncontents.p: To build, run and test this sample, you must have a v4 print driver and a print queue already installed. The sample should be saved to c:\apps.
Perform the following steps to build the sample.

desc.mark: Add your PrinterDriverID to the PrinterExtensionSample

list.item:
1. Find your PrinterDriverID
a. Open PowerShell
b. Type the following script to find your printer where “printer name” is the name of your print queue. $printDriverID = Get-Content ((Get-Printer "Printer name” | Get-PrinterDriver).DependentFiles | Where-Object -FilterScript:{$_ -like "*manifest.ini"}) | Where-Object -FilterScript:{$_ -like "PrinterDriverId*"} ($printDriverID.Split("="))[1];
c. Copy the GUID value that was output, including both curly braces {}.

2. Add the PrinterDriverID to the printer extension
a. Open .
b. In Solution Explorer, expand PrinterExtensionSample, then right click on App.xaml. Choose View Code.
c. Scroll to the bottom of the file, and edit the variable PrinterDriverID. Select everything inside the double-quotes and paste.

3. Build the project
a. In Solution Explorer, right click on the PrinterExtensionSample solution and choose Build Solution.

item.p: 4. In the Find textbox type {PrinterDriverId}, and in the Replace textbox type the PrinterDriverID value that you found using Powershell.
5. Open , click Tools > Create Guid. Select Registry Format > Copy.
6. Go back to Notepad and click Edit > Replace. Find {PrinterExtensionId} and replace it with the GUID you just created.
7. Click File > Save, and Save this file in C:\Apps\PrinterExtensionSample. Name the file register.reg. Change the file type to All files.
8. Open a Windows Explorer window and navigate to C:\apps\PrinterExtensionSample.
9. Double-click the register.reg file and click yes on any prompts.

sectioncontents.p: For information on how to build a driver solution using , see Building a Driver.

item.p: 1. Open an app that supports printing, for example Notepad. Then click File > Print.
2. In the print window, select your print queue, and then click Preferences. This should launch your PrinterExtensionSample app.

sectioncontents.p: If your app is not launched, the registration request may have failed, or the request may not have been processed in time. Try launching the app again, and if it continues to fail, confirm that the PrintNotify service is running.

In order to debug your sample at startup, it is useful to create a MessageBox in the beginning of the OnDriverEvent method of App.xaml.cs. Once your app is running and the MessageBox is visible, you can attach to it using Visual Studio.
1. Debug your sample using Visual Studio.
a. In , click Debug > Attach to Process.
b. Find PrinterExtensionSample.exe in the list, then select Attach.
c. Set any relevant breakpoints, then click OK in the MessageBox to continue.

seealso.xref: v4 Print Driver Interfaces and Enumerations
